article.description: For a team ranked in the Top 10 and in the thick of the Big 12 race, Texas coach Jody Conradt feels her Longhorns have been overlooked most of this season.
article.headline: Texas believes recognition coming slowly
article.linkText: Hard to overlook 'Horns after routing Colorado
article.story:
AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- For a team ranked in the Top 10 and in the
thick of the Big 12 race, Texas coach Jody Conradt feels her
Longhorns have been overlooked most of this season.

	   With more wins like Wednesday night's 75-55 roll over Colorado,
it's unlikely the nation won't figure out what's going on in
Austin.

	   Heather Schreiber scored 17 points and grabbed 13 rebounds as
No. 10 Texas ran its home record to 13-0 this season. Texas has won
six in a row and 11 of its last 12 overall.

	   ``People are starting to recognize we're a pretty good team,''
said Conradt, whose team cracked the Top 10 this week for the first
time in six years. ``Recognition has been, in my mind, a little
slow in coming. I think we've been a Top 10 team for some time. I
think we can play with anyone in the country.''

	   Texas (18-5, 11-1 Big 12) already proved that with wins over
Tennessee and Texas Tech. But the Longhorns also had a string of
early-season road losses Conradt believes held them back.

	   ``Everybody wants to focus on the record, and yes, we have five
losses,'' Conradt said. ``I think this is a team that is
talented.''

	   Texas showed that by spreading the scoring around against
Colorado.

	   Jamie Carey scored 15 points and Stacy Stephens added 14 points
and 10 rebounds for the Longhorns, who outrebounded Colorado 45-33
and held the Buffaloes to 31 percent shooting.

	   ``There were plays tonight when we knew someone was going to be
there,'' said Stephens, a player of year award finalist who got her
eighth double-double. ``We have to trust that instinct.''

	   Randie Wirt scored 11 points to lead Colorado (18-5, 8-4), which
never recovered from an early double-digit deficit and 6-foot-5
center Tera Bjorklund's foul trouble.

	   Bjorklund came in averaging 16.4 points, but had just 10 against
Texas, spending most of the game on the bench in foul trouble.

	   ``She's one of our go-to scorers,'' said Colorado coach Ceal
Barry. ``Our bigger problem came more from the outside. We missed
some shots.''

	   Texas put Colorado in a hole from the start, forcing the
Buffaloes into five turnovers on their first six possessions.
Bjorklund picked up two quick fouls and played just seven minutes
in the first half.

	   Meanwhile, Schreiber had 11 points and seven rebounds before the
break.

	   Texas opened up a 35-18 lead, but Colorado made nine of 10 free
throws in the final three minutes of the half to close to 37-25.

	   Texas kept up the pressure in the second. Stephens hit a quick
layup around Bjorklund, Schreiber hit a 3-pointer and Carey hit
another from long range at the Longhorns opened up a 55-33 lead
with 13:23 left.

	   Texas is tied with Kansas State at the top of the Big 12
standings, although the Wildcats would own the tiebreaker with
their 71-69 win over the Longhorns on Jan. 25.

	   The Longhorns have never won the Big 12, but Carey says they
aren't thinking about it yet. Next up is another home game Saturday
against lowly Nebraska.

	   ``It doesn't get much better than being in the Top 10,'' Carey
said.
